Postmodern art, emerging in the mid-1960s, represents the artistic manifestation of postmodernity, a socio-cultural theory that posits the existence of a contemporary age succeeding the modern project. This contemporary era is characterized culturally by the Enlightenment, politically by the French Revolution, and economically by the Industrial Revolution. In contrast to the preceding hyperrealism and neo-luminism movements, postmodern art breaks away from traditional artistic styles and conventions as a reaction to modern art.

Postmodern artists believe that avant-garde movements have fallen short, marking the modern project's failure. While the avant-garde aimed to merge art and life and make it universal, postmodern artists focus on self-referentiality, meaning art is about art itself.

In alignment with postmodern thought, the artists of this movement hold the view that art should be centered around self-referentiality, focusing on art itself, rather than trying to impact society or fulfill a social purpose as the avant-garde movements attempted.
